answer.explanation: Fiat currency is a government-issued currency that is not backed by a commodity such as gold. Currencies like the US Dollar or the Canadian dollar are examples of fiat currency.

contents.prompt: Which of the following are examples of fiat currency? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: False! Although many cryptocurrencies do have their own network many others rely on the infrastructure provided by an existing network.

contents.prompt: All cryptocurrencies rely on their own blockchain network.

answer.explanation: Turing complete refers to the ability for a system to do anything a turing machine can do. A turing machine (in theory) is capable of computing anything. The only turing incomplete technology that was listed was Bitcoin. This makes Bitcoin a fairly limited system that's sole use case is decenteralized finance.

contents.prompt: Which of the following technologies are considered turing complete? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation:
The main difference between Ethereum and Bitcoin is that Ethereum is a platform that allows the creation of DApps, while Bitcoin only provides decentralized finance. Ethereum is turing complete which allows for the support of smart contracts and the execution of complex logic and programs, while Bitcoin is turing incomplete.

Neither Ethereum or Bitcoin is objectively cheaper, faster or more secure than the other, they are simply different technologies with different advantages and disadvantages.

choices: Bitcoin is turing complete while Ethereum is turing incomplete.
Ethereum is a platform that can be built upon, while Bitcoin is only useful for decentralized finance.
Ethereum supports decenteralized applications and smart contract while Bitcoin does not.
Bitcoin is faster and more secure than Ethereum.
Ethereum always has lower transaction fees than Bitcoin.
contents.prompt: What are the major differences between Ethereum and Bitcoin? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: Smart contracts are simply code that is hosted on the blockchain. This means they have properties similar to that of a blockchain network. Like regular accounts smart contracts have an address and may hold a balance. All operations related to the smart contract are traceable, transparent and publicly available and anyone can view the code of a smart contract. Smart contract code can be executed by various nodes on the network, not just miners. Smart contracts are immutable and cannot be modified once deployed.

contents.prompt: Which of the following are characteristics of smart contracts hosted on Ethereum? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: True! For example, Ether is the default cryptocurrency for Ethereum but thousands of other unique tokens exist on the Ethereum network.

contents.prompt: A coin is the default cryptocurrency of a blockchain network, while a token is created using a smart contract.

answer.explanation: Tokens deployed on the Ethereum network follow the ERC-20 protocol. This protocol standardizes the core functionality of each token.

contents.prompt: A token on the Ethereum network follows which protocol?

answer.explanation: Fungible refers to the ability to replace or to be replaced by another identical item. In this context a US $1 bill is fungible. This is because any $1 bill has the same value, if you swap a $1 bill with me we still both have $1 in value. The same explanation applies for Bitcoin, if we swap 1 BTC we still have the same value. This does not apply for unique items like NFTs (ERC-721 Tokens) or assets like pieces of art.

contents.prompt: Which of the following assets/items would be considered fungible.

answer.explanation: Layer-1 refers to a base network and it's underlying infrastructure. Layer-1 blockchains can validate and finalize transactions without the reliance on another network.

contents.prompt: Which of the following technologies are examples of Layer-1 Chains? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation: False! Although many stablecoins are backed by commodities, fiat currency or other stablecoins there are some that are not. These are referred to as algorithmic stablecoins.

contents.prompt: All stablecoins are backed by some commodity, fiat currency, or other cryptocurrencies.

answer.explanation: False! Although rare, it is possible for a stablecoin to lose it's peg and this has happened. When a stablecoin loses it's peg it's value drops below the price of the underlying asset.

contents.prompt: It is impossible for a stablecoin to lose its peg.

answer.explanation: False! Smart contracts can only read/access information that is on the blockchain. Smart contracts cannot call APIs or use HTTP requests directly.

contents.prompt: Smart contracts can call APIs and make HTTP requests.

answer.explanation: An oracle is any device or entity that connects blockchains with off-chain data. Oracles are very useful for getting outside data onto the blockchain, while ensuring that data is valid and verified.

choices: Any device or entity that connects blockchains with off-chain data.
Any blockchain network that allows for HTTP requests.
A set of APIs that can be used by the blockchain.
A blockchain that can look outside of it's own code.
A special ERC-20 contract that injects off-chain data onto the blockchain.
contents.prompt: In the context of blockchains, what is an Oracle? Select the most accurate option.

answer.explanation: A decentralized Oracle network is essential to maintain the security and usefulness of smart contracts. If you were to rely on a single Oracle, specifically a single node providing your smart contract with data, you would open your code up to massive security vulnerabilities. Using a single data source would allow the entity controlling that to essentially control your smart contract and remove the purpose of having it on the blockchain in the first place. Using a decentralized Oracle network is essential to ensure that data is correct, verifiable and cannot be controlled by a single entity. These Oracles networks do not necessarily increase speed or reduce transaction costs.

choices: To ensure data stays consistent and is verifiable.
To ensure multiple data sources/entities agree on data before it's posted to the blockchain.
To increase the speed of using an Oracle.
To reduce the cost of using an Oracle.
To reduce the security risks of using a single Oracle in a smart contract.
contents.prompt: Why is it important to use a decentralized Oracle network? Select all that apply.

answer.explanation:
The three vertices of the scalability trilemma are Scalability, Decentralization and Security. They follow the relationships defined below.

  • Having high scalability and security decreases decentralization.
  • Having high scalability and decentralization decrease security.
  • Having high security and decentralization decrease scalability.

contents.prompt: What are the three vertices of the scalability trilemma? Select all that apply.
